english: beauty that sinks fish and makes birds fall

etymology.description: 沉(沈) (chén, "sink") is paired with 鱼(魚) (yú, "fish") and 落(落) (luò, "fall") is paired with 雁(雁) (yàn, "wild goose"). The phrase 沉鱼落雁(沈魚落雁) (chén yú luò yàn) describes a beauty so profound that fish forget to swim and sink, while geese are so entranced they forget to fly and fall.
etymology.interpretation: In classical Chinese literature, 沉鱼落雁(沈魚落雁) (chén yú luò yàn) is a description of overwhelming beauty that captivates the natural world; it's often used to praise exceptional feminine beauty.
etymology.simplification: traditional simplified to 沉鱼落雁

examples.chinese: 她的容貌沉鱼落雁(她的容貌沉魚落雁)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de róngmào chén yú luò yàn.
examples.english: Her beauty is so extraordinary that it could sink fish and make birds fall.

examples.chinese: 那位佳人走进宴会上(那位佳人走進宴會上)，令众人惊叹沉鱼落雁(令眾人驚嘆沉魚落雁)。
examples.pinyin: Nà wèi jiā rén zǒu jìn yànhuì shàng, lìng zhòngrén jīngtàn chén yú luò yàn.
examples.english: That beauty walked into the banquet, leaving everyone in awe with her sink-fish and falling-bird charm.
